intro: Acaena alboffii, commonly known as the white-fruited burrplant, is a perennial shrub native to New Zealand. It belongs to the family Rosaceae and is characterized by its dense, spiny foliage and small, spherical fruits. The plant produces yellow flowers that bloom in late spring, followed by the development of hairy, spiky fruits that contain seeds. Acaena alboffii is adapted to a variety of soil types and can thrive in both full sun and partial shade. Its unique morphology makes it an interesting subject for ecological and botanical study.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena alboffii is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the South Island, particularly in the central and southern regions. This plant thrives in a variety of habitats, including grasslands, shrublands, and coastal areas. It is commonly associated with the lower mountain ranges and is often found in disturbed or open environments. Acaena alboffii is an important component of the native flora in these regions.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena alboffii was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It is commonly found in coastal and lowland areas, particularly in the North Island. The plant thrives in disturbed soils and is often seen along roadsides and in urban environments. It is considered an invasive species due to its rapid growth and ability to outcompete native vegetation. Its distribution has expanded significantly since its introduction, posing a threat to local ecosystems.
